listDisplay.secondary: Creator God, Progenitor of the Gods, Lord of Creation

subtitle: The Male Who Invites - Progenitor of the Gods

gridDisplay.subtitle: The Male Who Invites - Progenitor of the Gods

hoverInfo.quick: Creator god who shaped Japan and fathered the sun, moon, and storm

gridDisplay.title: Izanagi-no-Mikoto

name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto

narratives.title: The Heavenly Mandate to Create
narratives.summary: The heavenly kami gave Izanagi and Izanami the Ame-no-nuboko (Heavenly Jeweled Spear) and commanded them to solidify and shape the drifting land. Standing on the Floating Bridge of Heaven, they stirred the primordial ocean, and when they lifted the spear, the brine that dripped formed the island Onogoro.
narratives.significance: Establishes divine authority to create and order the world

narratives.title: Birth of the Islands
narratives.summary: On Onogoro Island, Izanagi and Izanami performed a wedding ritual circling the Heavenly Pillar. Their first attempt failed because Izanami spoke first. On the second attempt, Izanagi spoke first, and they successfully gave birth to the eight great islands of Japan and numerous kami.
narratives.significance: Establishes proper ritual order and gender hierarchy in creation

narratives.title: The Death of Izanami
narratives.summary: When Izanami gave birth to Kagutsuchi, the fire god, she was fatally burned. Despite Izanagi's grief and rage (he killed the fire god, from whose body more kami were born), Izanami descended to Yomi, the land of the dead.
narratives.significance: Introduction of death into the world; origin of many important kami

narratives.title: The Descent to Yomi
narratives.summary: Izanagi pursued Izanami to Yomi. She told him not to look upon her, but he lit a torch and saw her rotting, maggot-ridden corpse surrounded by the thunder kami. Horrified, he fled as Izanami sent the hags of Yomi and the thunder kami to pursue him. At the border, he blocked the passage with a great boulder.
narratives.significance: Establishes the barrier between life and death; parallels to Orpheus myth

narratives.title: The Purification and Birth of the Three Precious Children
narratives.summary: Polluted by death, Izanagi performed misogi (purification) at the river mouth at Tachibana. As he washed, many kami were born. From his left eye came Amaterasu, from his right eye came Tsukuyomi, and from his nose came Susanoo. He assigned them dominion over heaven, night, and sea.
narratives.significance: Origin of the three greatest kami; establishes misogi as foundational to Shinto

search.searchableText: izanagi-no-mikoto creator god progenitor shinto creation primordial purification misogi

description: Izanagi-no-Mikoto is the primordial creator god of Japanese mythology who, together with his sister-wife Izanami, gave birth to the islands of Japan and countless kami. After losing Izanami to death and failing to rescue her from Yomi, his purification ritual gave birth to Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, and Susanoo - the three greatest kami.

historicalContext.historicalPeriod: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)
historicalContext.sourceText: Kojiki - Book 1: Creation myth; Nihon Shoki - Primordial deities

shrineSites.name: Izanagi Shrine (Izanagi-jingu)
shrineSites.notes: One of the oldest shrines in Japan, associated with the first land created

shrineSites.name: Taga Taisha
shrineSites.significance: Important shrine where Izanagi is said to have retired

festivalAssociations.name: Izanagi Matsuri
festivalAssociations.significance: Celebration of creation and primordial deity

imperialConnections.imperialLegitimacy: Grandfather of Amaterasu - grandfather of imperial line

historicalNotes: Creation myth parallels: Mesopotamian, Polynesian traditions
Shinto concept of purification (misogi) originating from his cleansing
Yomi (underworld) visit establishes death realm mythology
Divine procreation through ritual, not physical union in later tradition

practices: Misogi (ritual purification) derived from his cleansing
Prayers for creation, new beginnings, and fertility
Offerings for safe childbirth and healthy children

sacredObjects.name: Ame-no-nuboko (Heavenly Jeweled Spear)
sacredObjects.description: The spear used to stir the primordial ocean and create land
sacredObjects.symbolism: Divine power to create order from chaos

sacredObjects.name: Heavenly Pillar
sacredObjects.description: The pillar around which Izanagi and Izanami performed their wedding ritual

primary.title: Kojiki
primary.author: O no Yasumaro
primary.description: Record of Ancient Matters - most complete creation narrative

primary.title: Nihon Shoki
primary.author: Prince Toneri et al.
primary.description: Chronicles of Japan - variant creation accounts

Amaterasu-Omikami
children.note: Born from left eye during misogi

children.name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto
children.note: Born from right eye during misogi

divineRelationships.spouse: Izanami - whom he lost to death and could not rescue
divineRelationships.commander: The heavenly kami who ordered creation

symbolism.archetype: Creator God - primordial power bringing order from chaos
